poem:
**The Permeable Line**

A whisper slips  
through the thin veil,  
where spirits float back  
from dusk to dawn,  
and bodies, soft as wax,  
bend to shadows' will.  
What hope in locked doors,  
when within,  
we are but water,  
waiting  
to spill?
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Good and Evil and Other Stories by Samanta Schweblin review – grasping the essence of horror Horror, in essence, is about porousness. Our terrors take varied forms but horror probes their single, existential source: the terrifying permeability of our boundaries. If spirits can swim back from the world of the dead, if the living body can degrade to the point where it becomes malleable or parasitically possessed, what hope can there be for our fantasy of security". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
